dialogues.text: We should start back. The wildlings are dead.
dialogues.speaker: Gared

dialogues.text: Do the dead frighten you?
dialogues.speaker: Waymar Royce

dialogues.text: Dead is dead. We have no business with the dead.
dialogues.speaker: Gared

dialogues.text: Are they dead? What proof have we?
dialogues.speaker: Waymar Royce

dialogues.text: Will saw them. If he says they are dead, that's proof enough for me.
dialogues.speaker: Gared

dialogues.text: My mother told me that dead men sing no songs.
dialogues.speaker: Will

dialogues.text: My wet nurse said the same thing, Will. Never believe anything you hear at a woman's tit. There are things to be learned even from the dead.
dialogues.speaker: Waymar Royce

dialogues.text: We have a long ride before us, eight days, maybe nine. And night is falling.
dialogues.speaker: Gared

dialogues.text: It does that every day about this time. Are you unmanned by the dark, Gared?
dialogues.speaker: Waymar Royce

dialogues.text: Mormont said as we should track them, and we did. They're dead. They shan't trouble us no more. There's hard riding before us. I don't like this weather. If it snows, we could be a fortnight getting back, and snow's the best we can hope for. Ever seen an ice storm, my lord?
dialogues.speaker: Gared

dialogues.text: Tell me again what you saw, Will. All the details. Leave nothing out.
dialogues.speaker: Waymar Royce

dialogues.text: The camp is two miles farther on, over that ridge, hard beside a stream. I got close as I dared. There's eight of them, men and women both. No children I could see. They put up a lean-to against the rock. The snow's pretty well covered it now, but I could still make it out. No fire burning, but the firepit was still plain as day. No one moving. I watched a long time. No living man ever lay so still.
dialogues.speaker: Will

dialogues.text: Did you see any blood?
dialogues.speaker: Waymar Royce

dialogues.text: Well, no.
dialogues.speaker: Will

dialogues.text: Did you see any weapons?
dialogues.speaker: Waymar Royce

dialogues.text: Some swords, a few bows. One man had an axe. Heavy-looking, double-bladed, a cruel piece of iron. It was on the ground beside him, right by his hand.
dialogues.speaker: Will

dialogues.text: Did you make note of the position of the bodies?
dialogues.speaker: Waymar Royce

dialogues.text: A couple are sitting up against the rock. Most of them on the ground. Fallen, like.
dialogues.speaker: Will

dialogues.text: Or sleeping.
dialogues.speaker: Waymar Royce

dialogues.text: Fallen. There's one woman up an ironwood, half-hid in the branches. A far-eyes. I took care she never saw me. When I got closer, I saw that she wasn't moving neither.
dialogues.speaker: Will

dialogues.text: You have a chill?
dialogues.speaker: Waymar Royce

dialogues.text: Some. The wind, my lord.
dialogues.speaker: Will

dialogues.text: What do you think might have killed these men, Gared?
dialogues.speaker: Waymar Royce

dialogues.text: It was the cold. I saw men freeze last winter, and the one before, when I was half a boy. Everyone talks about snows forty foot deep, and how the ice wind comes howling out of the north, but the real enemy is the cold. It steals up on you quieter than Will, and at first you shiver and your teeth chatter and you stamp your feet and dream of mulled wine and nice hot fires. It burns, it does. Nothing burns like the cold. But only for a while. Then it gets inside you and starts to fill you up, and after a while you don't have the strength to fight it. It's easier just to sit down or go to sleep. They say you don't feel any pain toward the end. First you go weak and drowsy, and everything starts to fade, and then it's like sinking into a sea of warm milk. Peaceful, like.
dialogues.speaker: Gared

dialogues.text: Such eloquence, Gared. I never suspected you had it in you.
dialogues.speaker: Waymar Royce

dialogues.text: I've had the cold in me too, lordling. Two ears, three toes, and the little finger off my left hand. I got off light. We found my brother frozen at his watch, with a smile on his face.
dialogues.speaker: Gared

dialogues.text: You ought dress more warmly, Gared.
dialogues.speaker: Waymar Royce

dialogues.text: We'll see how warm you can dress when the winter comes.
dialogues.speaker: Gared

dialogues.text: If Gared said it was the cold…
dialogues.speaker: Will

dialogues.text: Have you drawn any watches this past week, Will?
dialogues.speaker: Waymar Royce

dialogues.text: Yes, m'lord.
dialogues.speaker: Will

dialogues.text: And how did you find the Wall?
dialogues.speaker: Waymar Royce

dialogues.text: Weeping.
dialogues.speaker: Will

dialogues.text: They couldn't have froze. Not if the Wall was weeping. It wasn't cold enough.
dialogues.speaker: Will

dialogues.text: Bright lad. We've had a few light frosts this past week, and a quick flurry of snow now and then, but surely no cold fierce enough to kill eight grown men. Men clad in fur and leather, let me remind you, with shelter near at hand, and the means of making fire.
dialogues.speaker: Waymar Royce

dialogues.text: Will, lead us there. I would see these dead men for myself.
dialogues.speaker: Waymar Royce

dialogues.text: We can make a better pace than this, surely.
dialogues.speaker: Waymar Royce

dialogues.text: Not with this horse. Perhaps my lord would care to take the lead?
dialogues.speaker: Will

dialogues.text: Why are you stopping?
dialogues.speaker: Waymar Royce

dialogues.text: Best go the rest of the way on foot, m'lord. It's just over that ridge.
dialogues.speaker: Will

dialogues.text: There's something wrong here.
dialogues.speaker: Gared

dialogues.text: Is there?
dialogues.speaker: Waymar Royce

dialogues.text: Can't you feel it? Listen to the darkness.
dialogues.speaker: Gared

dialogues.text: Wind. Trees rustling. A wolf. Which sound is it that unmans you so, Gared?
dialogues.speaker: Waymar Royce

dialogues.text: The trees press close here. That sword will tangle you up, m'lord. Better a knife.
dialogues.speaker: Will

dialogues.text: If I need instruction, I will ask for it.
dialogues.speaker: Waymar Royce

dialogues.text: Gared, stay here. Guard the horses.
dialogues.speaker: Waymar Royce

dialogues.text: We need a fire. I'll see to it.
dialogues.speaker: Gared

dialogues.text: How big a fool are you, old man? If there are enemies in this wood, a fire is the last thing we want.
dialogues.speaker: Waymar Royce

dialogues.text: There's some enemies a fire will keep away. Bears and direwolves and… and other things…
dialogues.speaker: Gared

dialogues.text: No fire.
dialogues.speaker: Waymar Royce

dialogues.text: No fire.
dialogues.speaker: Gared

dialogues.text: Lead on.
dialogues.speaker: Waymar Royce

dialogues.text: Gods!
dialogues.speaker: Waymar Royce

dialogues.text: Get down! Something's wrong.
dialogues.speaker: Will

dialogues.text: Your dead men seem to have moved camp, Will.
dialogues.speaker: Waymar Royce

dialogues.text: On your feet, Will. There's no one here. I won't have you hiding under a bush.
dialogues.speaker: Waymar Royce

dialogues.text: I am not going back to Castle Black a failure on my first ranging. We will find these men. Up the tree. Be quick about it. Look for a fire.
dialogues.speaker: Waymar Royce

dialogues.text: Who goes there?
dialogues.speaker: Waymar Royce

dialogues.text: Will, where are you? Can you see anything?
dialogues.speaker: Waymar Royce

dialogues.text: Answer me! Why is it so cold?
dialogues.speaker: Waymar Royce

dialogues.text: Come no farther.
dialogues.speaker: Waymar Royce

dialogues.text: Dance with me then.
dialogues.speaker: Waymar Royce

dialogues.text: For Robert!
dialogues.speaker: Waymar Royce

dialogues.text: [Unknown words in an unknown language]
dialogues.speaker: Unknown (The Others)

dialogues.text: In the name of Robert of the House Baratheon, the First of his Name, King of the Andals and the Rhoynar and the First Men, Lord of the Seven Kingdoms and Protector of the Realm, by the word of Eddard of the House Stark, Lord of Winterfell and Warden of the North, I do sentence you to die.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Keep the pony well in hand. And don't look away. Father will know if you do.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: Ass.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: You did well.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: The deserter died bravely. He had courage, at the least.
dialogues.speaker: Robb Stark

dialogues.text: No. It was not courage. This one was dead of fear. You could see it in his eyes, Stark.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: The Others take his eyes. He died well. Race you to the bridge?
dialogues.speaker: Robb Stark

dialogues.text: Done.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: Are you well, Bran?
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Yes, Father. Robb says the man died bravely, but Jon says he was afraid.
dialogues.speaker: Bran Stark

dialogues.text: What do you think?
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Can a man still be brave if he's afraid?
dialogues.speaker: Bran Stark

dialogues.text: That is the only time a man can be brave. Do you understand why I did it?
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: He was a wildling. They carry off women and sell them to the Others.
dialogues.speaker: Bran Stark

dialogues.text: Old Nan has been telling you stories again. In truth, the man was an oathbreaker, a deserter from the Night's Watch. No man is more dangerous. The deserter knows his life is forfeit if he is taken, so he will not flinch from any crime, no matter how vile. But you mistake me. The question was not why the man had to die, but why I must do it.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: King Robert has a headsman.
dialogues.speaker: Bran Stark

dialogues.text: He does. As did the Targaryen kings before him. Yet our way is the older way. The blood of the First Men still flows in the veins of the Starks, and we hold to the belief that the man who passes the sentence should swing the sword. If you would take a man's life, you owe it to him to look into his eyes and hear his final words. And if you cannot bear to do that, then perhaps the man does not deserve to die. One day, Bran, you will be Robb's bannerman, holding a keep of your own for your brother and your king, and justice will fall to you. When that day comes, you must take no pleasure in the task, but neither must you look away. A ruler who hides behind paid executioners soon forgets what death is.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Father, Bran, come quickly, see what Robb has found!
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: Trouble, my lord?
dialogues.speaker: Jory Cassel

dialogues.text: Beyond a doubt. Come, let us see what mischief my sons have rooted out now.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Gods!
dialogues.speaker: Theon Greyjoy

dialogues.text: Robb, get away from it!
dialogues.speaker: Jory Cassel

dialogues.text: She can't hurt you. She's dead, Jory.
dialogues.speaker: Robb Stark

dialogues.text: What in the seven hells is it?
dialogues.speaker: Theon Greyjoy

dialogues.text: A wolf.
dialogues.speaker: Robb Stark

dialogues.text: A freak. Look at the size of it.
dialogues.speaker: Theon Greyjoy

dialogues.text: It's no freak. That's a direwolf. They grow larger than the other kind.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: There's not been a direwolf sighted south of the Wall in two hundred years.
dialogues.speaker: Theon Greyjoy

dialogues.text: I see one now.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: Go on. You can touch him.
dialogues.speaker: Robb Stark

dialogues.text: Here you go. There are five of them.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: Direwolves loose in the realm, after so many years. I like it not.
dialogues.speaker: Hullen

dialogues.text: It is a sign.
dialogues.speaker: Jory Cassel

dialogues.text: This is only a dead animal, Jory. Do we know what killed her?
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: There's something in the throat. There, just under the jaw.
dialogues.speaker: Robb Stark

dialogues.text: I'm surprised she lived long enough to whelp.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Maybe she didn't.
dialogues.speaker: Jory Cassel

dialogues.text: I've heard tales… maybe the bitch was already dead when the pups came.
dialogues.speaker: Theon Greyjoy

dialogues.text: Born with the dead. Worst luck.
dialogues.speaker: Unknown (Another man)

dialogues.text: No matter. They be dead soon enough too.
dialogues.speaker: Hullen

dialogues.text: The sooner the better. Give the beast here, Bran.
dialogues.speaker: Theon Greyjoy

dialogues.text: No! It's mine.
dialogues.speaker: Bran Stark

dialogues.text: Put away your sword, Greyjoy. We will keep these pups.
dialogues.speaker: Robb Stark

dialogues.text: You cannot do that, boy.
dialogues.speaker: Harwin

dialogues.text: It be a mercy to kill them.
dialogues.speaker: Hullen

dialogues.text: Hullen speaks truly, son. Better a swift death than a hard one from cold and starvation.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: No!
dialogues.speaker: Bran Stark

dialogues.text: Ser Rodrik's red bitch whelped again last week. It was a small litter, only two live pups. She'll have milk enough.
dialogues.speaker: Robb Stark

dialogues.text: She'll rip them apart when they try to nurse.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Lord Stark. There are five pups. Three male, two female.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: What of it, Jon?
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: You have five trueborn children. Three sons, two daughters. The direwolf is the sigil of your House. Your children were meant to have these pups, my lord.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: You want no pup for yourself, Jon?
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: The direwolf graces the banners of House Stark. I am no Stark, Father.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: I will nurse him myself, Father. I will soak a towel with warm milk, and give him suck from that.
dialogues.speaker: Robb Stark

dialogues.text: Me too!
dialogues.speaker: Bran Stark

dialogues.text: Easy to say, and harder to do. I will not have you wasting the servants' time with this. If you want these pups, you will feed them yourselves. Is that understood?
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: You must train them as well. You must train them. The kennelmaster will have nothing to do with these monsters, I promise you that. And the gods help you if you neglect them, or brutalize them, or train them badly. These are not dogs to beg for treats and slink off at a kick. A direwolf will rip a man's arm off his shoulder as easily as a dog will kill a rat. Are you sure you want this?
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Yes, Father.
dialogues.speaker: Bran Stark

dialogues.text: Yes.
dialogues.speaker: Robb Stark

dialogues.text: The pups may die anyway, despite all you do.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: They won't die. We won't let them die.
dialogues.speaker: Bran Stark

dialogues.text: Keep them, then. Jory, Desmond, gather up the other pups. It's time we were back to Winterfell.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: What is it, Jon?
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Can't you hear it? There. He must have crawled away from the others.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: Or been driven away.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: An albino. This one will die even faster than the others.
dialogues.speaker: Theon Greyjoy

dialogues.text: I think not, Greyjoy. This one belongs to me.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: Ned.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: Catelyn.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Where are the children?
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: In the kitchen, arguing about names for the wolf pups. Arya is already in love, and Sansa is charmed and gracious, but Rickon is not quite sure.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: Is he afraid?
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: A little. He is only three.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: He must learn to face his fears. He will not be three forever. And winter is coming.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Yes.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: The man died well, I'll give him that. I was glad for Bran's sake. You would have been proud of Bran.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: I am always proud of Bran.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: He was the fourth this year. The poor man was half-mad. Something had put a fear in him so deep that my words could not reach him. Ben writes that the strength of the Night's Watch is down below a thousand. It's not only desertions. They are losing men on rangings as well.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Is it the wildlings?
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: Who else? And it will only grow worse. The day may come when I will have no choice but to call the banners and ride north to deal with this King-beyond-the-Wall for good and all.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Beyond the Wall?
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: Mance Rayder is nothing for us to fear.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: There are darker things beyond the Wall.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: You listen to too many of Old Nan's stories. The Others are as dead as the children of the forest, gone eight thousand years. Maester Luwin will tell you they never lived at all. No living man has ever seen one.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Until this morning, no living man had ever seen a direwolf either.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: I ought to know better than to argue with a Tully. You did not come here to tell me crib tales. I know how little you like this place. What is it, my lady?
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: There was grievous news today, my lord. I did not wish to trouble you until you had cleansed yourself. I am so sorry, my love. Jon Arryn is dead.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: Jon… Is this news certain?
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: It was the king's seal, and the letter is in Robert's own hand. I saved it for you. He said Lord Arryn was taken quickly. Even Maester Pycelle was helpless, but he brought the milk of the poppy, so Jon did not linger long in pain.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: That is some small mercy, I suppose. Your sister. And Jon's boy. What word of them?
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: The message said only that they were well, and had returned to the Eyrie. I wish they had gone to Riverrun instead. The Eyrie is high and lonely, and it was ever her husband's place, not hers. Lord Jon's memory will haunt each stone. I know my sister. She needs the comfort of family and friends around her.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: Your uncle waits in the Vale, does he not? Jon named him Knight of the Gate, I'd heard.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Brynden will do what he can for her, and for the boy. That is some comfort, but still…
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: Go to her. Take the children. Fill her halls with noise and shouts and laughter. That boy of hers needs other children about him, and Lysa should not be alone in her grief.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Would that I could. The letter had other tidings. The king is riding to Winterfell to seek you out.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: Robert is coming here?
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: I knew that would please you. We should send word to your brother on the Wall.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: Yes, of course. Ben will want to be here. I shall tell Maester Luwin to send his swiftest bird. Damnation, how many years has it been? And he gives us no more notice than this? How many in his party, did the message say?
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: I should think a hundred knights, at the least, with all their retainers, and half again as many freeriders. Cersei and the children travel with them.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: Robert will keep an easy pace for their sakes. It is just as well. That will give us more time to prepare.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: The queen's brothers are also in the party.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: Well, if the price for Robert's company is an infestation of Lannisters, so be it. It sounds as though Robert is bringing half his court.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Where the king goes, the realm follows.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: It will be good to see the children. The youngest was still sucking at the Lannister woman's teat the last time I saw him. He must be, what, five by now?
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Prince Tommen is seven. The same age as Bran. Please, Ned, guard your tongue. The Lannister woman is our queen, and her pride is said to grow with every passing year.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: There must be a feast, of course, with singers, and Robert will want to hunt. I shall send Jory south with an honor guard to meet them on the kingsroad and escort them back. Gods, how are we going to feed them all? On his way already, you said? Damn the man. Damn his royal hide.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: This is beauty. Touch it. Go on. Caress the fabric.
dialogues.speaker: Viserys Targaryen

dialogues.text: Is it really mine?
dialogues.speaker: Daenerys Targaryen

dialogues.text: A gift from the Magister Illyrio. The color will bring out the violet in your eyes. And you shall have gold as well, and jewels of all sorts. Illyrio has promised. Tonight you must look like a princess.
dialogues.speaker: Viserys Targaryen

dialogues.text: Why does he give us so much? What does he want from us?
dialogues.speaker: Daenerys Targaryen

dialogues.text: Illyrio is no fool. The magister knows that I will not forget my friends when I come into my throne.
dialogues.speaker: Viserys Targaryen

dialogues.text: Illyrio will send the slaves to bathe you. Be sure you wash off the stink of the stables. Khal Drogo has a thousand horses, tonight he looks for a different sort of mount. You still slouch. Straighten yourself. Let them see that you have a woman's shape now. You will not fail me tonight. If you do, it will go hard for you. You don't want to wake the dragon, do you? Do you?
dialogues.speaker: Viserys Targaryen

dialogues.text: No.
dialogues.speaker: Daenerys Targaryen

dialogues.text: Good. When they write the history of my reign, sweet sister, they will say that it began tonight.
dialogues.speaker: Viserys Targaryen

dialogues.text: Come.
dialogues.speaker: Daenerys Targaryen

dialogues.text: Drogo is so rich that even his slaves wear golden collars. A hundred thousand men ride in his khalasar, and his palace in Vaes Dothrak has two hundred rooms and doors of solid silver.
dialogues.speaker: Unknown (Illyrio's servant)

dialogues.text: Now you look all a princess.
dialogues.speaker: Unknown (Illyrio's servant)

dialogues.text: Stand there. Turn around. Yes. Good. You look…
dialogues.speaker: Viserys Targaryen

dialogues.text: Regal. May the Lord of Light shower you with blessings on this most fortunate day, Princess Daenerys.
dialogues.speaker: Illyrio Mopatis

dialogues.text: She is a vision, Your Grace, a vision. Drogo will be enraptured
dialogues.speaker: Illyrio Mopatis

dialogues.text: She's too skinny. Are you sure that Khal Drogo likes his women this young?
dialogues.speaker: Viserys Targaryen

dialogues.text: She has had her blood. She is old enough for the khal. Look at her. That silver-gold hair, those purple eyes… she is the blood of old Valyria, no doubt, no doubt… and highborn, daughter of the old king, sister to the new, she cannot fail to entrance our Drogo.
dialogues.speaker: Illyrio Mopatis

dialogues.text: I suppose. The savages have queer tastes. Boys, horses, sheep…
dialogues.speaker: Viserys Targaryen

dialogues.text: Best not suggest this to Khal Drogo.
dialogues.speaker: Illyrio Mopatis

dialogues.text: Do you take me for a fool?
dialogues.speaker: Viserys Targaryen

dialogues.text: I take you for a king. Kings lack the caution of common men. My apologies if I have given offense.
dialogues.speaker: Illyrio Mopatis

dialogues.text: We won't need his whole khalasar. Ten thousand, that would be enough, I could sweep the Seven Kingdoms with ten thousand Dothraki screamers. The realm will rise for its rightful king. Tyrell, Redwyne, Darry, Greyjoy, they have no more love for the Usurper than I do. The Dornishmen burn to avenge Elia and her children. And the smallfolk will be with us. They cry out for their king. They do, don't they?
dialogues.speaker: Viserys Targaryen

dialogues.text: They are your people, and they love you well. In holdfasts all across the realm, men lift secret toasts to your health while women sew dragon banners and hide them against the day of your return from across the water. Or so my agents tell me.
dialogues.speaker: Illyrio Mopatis

dialogues.text: I shall kill the Usurper myself, as he killed my brother Rhaegar. And Lannister too, the Kingslayer, for what he did to my father.
dialogues.speaker: Viserys Targaryen

dialogues.text: That would be most fitting.
dialogues.speaker: Illyrio Mopatis

dialogues.text: Insolent eunuch.
dialogues.speaker: Viserys Targaryen

dialogues.text: Many important men will be at the feast tonight. Such men have enemies. The khal must protect his guests, yourself chief among them, Your Grace. No doubt the Usurper would pay well for your head.
dialogues.speaker: Illyrio Mopatis

dialogues.text: Oh, yes. He has tried, Illyrio, I promise you that. His hired knives follow us everywhere. I am the last dragon, and he will not sleep easy while I live.
dialogues.speaker: Viserys Targaryen

dialogues.text: Viserys of the House Targaryen, the Third of his Name, King of the Andals and the Rhoynar and the First Men, Lord of the Seven Kingdoms and Protector of the Realm. His sister, Daenerys Stormborn, Princess of Dragonstone. His honorable host, Illyrio Mopatis, Magister of the Free City of Pentos.
dialogues.speaker: Unknown (Palanquin)

dialogues.text: Those three are Drogo's bloodriders, there. By the pillar is Khal Moro, with his son Rhogoro. The man with the green beard is brother to the Archon of Tyrosh, and the man behind him is Ser Jorah Mormont.
dialogues.speaker: Illyrio Mopatis

dialogues.text: A knight?
dialogues.speaker: Daenerys Targaryen

dialogues.text: No less. Anointed with the seven oils by the High Septon himself.
dialogues.speaker: Illyrio Mopatis

dialogues.text: What is he doing here?
dialogues.speaker: Daenerys Targaryen

dialogues.text: The Usurper wanted his head. Some trifling affront. He sold some poachers to a Tyroshi slaver instead of giving them to the Night's Watch. Absurd law. A man should be able to do as he likes with his own chattel.
dialogues.speaker: Illyrio Mopatis

dialogues.text: I shall wish to speak with Ser Jorah before the night is done.
dialogues.speaker: Viserys Targaryen

dialogues.text: Over there, sweet princess, there is the khal himself.
dialogues.speaker: Illyrio Mopatis

dialogues.text: I must go and make my submissions. Wait here. I shall bring him to you.
dialogues.speaker: Illyrio Mopatis

dialogues.text: Do you see his braid, sweet sister? You see how long it is? When Dothraki are defeated in combat, they cut off their braids in disgrace, so the world will know their shame. Khal Drogo has never lost a fight. He is Aegon the Dragonlord come again, and you will be his queen.
dialogues.speaker: Viserys Targaryen

dialogues.text: I don't want to be his queen. Please, please, Viserys, I don't want to, I want to go home.
dialogues.speaker: Daenerys Targaryen

dialogues.text: Home? How are we to go home, sweet sister? They took our home from us! How are we to go home?
dialogues.speaker: Viserys Targaryen

dialogues.text: I don't know…
dialogues.speaker: Daenerys Targaryen

dialogues.text: I do. We go home with an army, sweet sister. With Khal Drogo's army, that is how we go home. And if you must wed him and bed him for that, you will. I'd let his whole khalasar fuck you if need be, sweet sister, all forty thousand men, and their horses too if that was what it took to get my army. Be grateful it is only Drogo. In time you may even learn to like him. Now dry your eyes. Illyrio is bringing him over, and he will not see you crying.
dialogues.speaker: Viserys Targaryen

dialogues.text: Smile. And stand up straight. Let him see that you have breasts. Gods know, you have little enough as is.
dialogues.speaker: Viserys Targaryen

dialogues.text: Ned! Ah, but it is good to see that frozen face of yours. You have not changed at all.
dialogues.speaker: Robert I Baratheon

dialogues.text: Your Grace. Winterfell is yours.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Take me down to your crypt, Eddard. I would pay my respects.
dialogues.speaker: Robert I Baratheon

dialogues.text: I was starting to think we would never reach Winterfell. In the south, the way they talk about my Seven Kingdoms, a man forgets that your part is as big as the other six combined.
dialogues.speaker: Robert I Baratheon

dialogues.text: I trust you enjoyed the journey, Your Grace?
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Bogs and forests and fields, and scarcely a decent inn north of the Neck. I've never seen such a vast emptiness. Where are all your people?
dialogues.speaker: Robert I Baratheon

dialogues.text: Likely they were too shy to come out. Kings are a rare sight in the north.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: More likely they were hiding under the snow. Snow, Ned!
dialogues.speaker: Robert I Baratheon

dialogues.text: Late summer snows are common enough. I hope they did not trouble you. They are usually mild.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: The Others take your mild snows. What will this place be like in winter? I shudder to think.
dialogues.speaker: Robert I Baratheon

dialogues.text: The winters are hard. But the Starks will endure. We always have.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: You need to come south. You need a taste of summer before it flees. In Highgarden there are fields of golden roses that stretch away as far as the eye can see. The fruits are so ripe they explode in your mouth—melons, peaches, fireplums, you've never tasted such sweetness. You'll see, I brought you some. Even at Storm's End, with that good wind off the bay, the days are so hot you can barely move. And you ought to see the towns, Ned! Flowers everywhere, the markets bursting with food, the summerwines so cheap and so good that you can get drunk just breathing the air. Everyone is fat and drunk and rich. And the girls, Ned! I swear, women lose all modesty in the heat. They swim naked in the river, right beneath the castle. Even in the streets, it's too damn hot for wool or fur, so they go around in these short gowns, silk if they have the silver and cotton if not, but it's all the same when they start sweating and the cloth sticks to their skin, they might as well be naked.
dialogues.speaker: Robert I Baratheon

dialogues.text: Your Grace. She is down at the end, with Father and Brandon. Here.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: She was more beautiful than that. Ah, damn it, Ned, did you have to bury her in a place like this? She deserved more than darkness…
dialogues.speaker: Robert I Baratheon

dialogues.text: She was a Stark of Winterfell. This is her place.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: She should be on a hill somewhere, under a fruit tree, with the sun and clouds above her and the rain to wash her clean.
dialogues.speaker: Robert I Baratheon

dialogues.text: I was with her when she died. She wanted to come home, to rest beside Brandon and Father. I bring her flowers when I can. Lyanna was… fond of flowers.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: I vowed to kill Rhaegar for what he did to her.
dialogues.speaker: Robert I Baratheon

dialogues.text: You did.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Only once. In my dreams, I kill him every night. A thousand deaths will still be less than he deserves.
dialogues.speaker: Robert I Baratheon

dialogues.text: We should return, Your Grace. Your wife will be waiting.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: The Others take my wife. And if I hear 'Your Grace' once more, I'll have your head on a spike. We are more to each other than that.
dialogues.speaker: Robert I Baratheon

dialogues.text: I had not forgotten. Tell me about Jon.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: I have never seen a man sicken so quickly. We gave a tourney on my son's name day. If you had seen Jon then, you would have sworn he would live forever. A fortnight later he was dead. The sickness was like a fire in his gut. It burned right through him. I loved that old man.
dialogues.speaker: Robert I Baratheon

dialogues.text: We both did. Catelyn fears for her sister. How does Lysa bear her grief?
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Not well, in truth. I think losing Jon has driven the woman mad, Ned. She has taken the boy back to the Eyrie. Against my wishes. I had hoped to foster him with Tywin Lannister at Casterly Rock. Jon had no brothers, no other sons. Was I supposed to leave him to be raised by women?
dialogues.speaker: Robert I Baratheon

dialogues.text: The wife has lost the husband. Perhaps the mother feared to lose the son. The boy is very young.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Six, and sickly, and Lord of the Eyrie, gods have mercy. Lord Tywin had never taken a ward before. Lysa ought to have been honored. The Lannisters are a great and noble House. She refused to even hear of it. Then she left in the dead of night, without so much as a by-your-leave. Cersei was furious. The boy is my namesake, did you know that? Robert Arryn. I am sworn to protect him. How can I do that if his mother steals him away?
dialogues.speaker: Robert I Baratheon

dialogues.text: I will take him as ward, if you wish. Lysa should consent to that. She and Catelyn were close as girls, and she would be welcome here as well.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: A generous offer, my friend, but too late. Lord Tywin has already given his consent. Fostering the boy elsewhere would be a grievous affront to him.
dialogues.speaker: Robert I Baratheon

dialogues.text: I have more concern for my nephew's welfare than I do for Lannister pride.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: That is because you do not sleep with a Lannister.
dialogues.speaker: Robert I Baratheon

dialogues.text: Ah, Ned, you are still too serious. I had planned to wait a few days to speak to you, but I see now there's no need for it. Come, walk with me. You must have wondered why I finally came north to Winterfell, after so long.
dialogues.speaker: Robert I Baratheon

dialogues.text: For the joy of my company, surely. And there is the Wall. You need to see it, Your Grace, to walk along its battlements and talk to those who man it. The Night's Watch is a shadow of what it once was. Benjen says—
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: No doubt I will hear what your brother says soon enough. The Wall has stood for what, eight thousand years? It can keep a few days more. I have more pressing concerns. These are difficult times. I need good men about me. Men like Jon Arryn. He served as Lord of the Eyrie, as Warden of the East, as the Hand of the King. He will not be easy to replace.
dialogues.speaker: Robert I Baratheon

dialogues.text: His son…
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: His son will succeed to the Eyrie and all its incomes. No more.
dialogues.speaker: Robert I Baratheon

dialogues.text: The Arryns have always been Wardens of the East. The title goes with the domain.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Perhaps when he comes of age, the honor can be restored to him. I have this year to think of, and next. A six-year-old boy is no war leader, Ned.
dialogues.speaker: Robert I Baratheon

dialogues.text: In peace, the title is only an honor. Let the boy keep it. For his father's sake if not his own. Surely you owe Jon that much for his service.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Jon's service was the duty he owed his liege lord. I am not ungrateful, Ned. You of all men ought to know that. But the son is not the father. A mere boy cannot hold the east. Enough of this. There is a more important office to discuss, and I would not argue with you. I have need of you, Ned.
dialogues.speaker: Robert I Baratheon

dialogues.text: I am yours to command, Your Grace. Always.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Those years we spent in the Eyrie… gods, those were good years. I want you at my side again, Ned. I want you down in King's Landing, not up here at the end of the world where you are no damned use to anybody. I swear to you, sitting a throne is a thousand times harder than winning one. Laws are a tedious business and counting coppers is worse. And the people… there is no end of them. I sit on that damnable iron chair and listen to them complain until my mind is numb and my ass is raw. They all want something, money or land or justice. The lies they tell… and my lords and ladies are no better. I am surrounded by flatterers and fools. It can drive a man to madness, Ned. Half of them don't dare tell me the truth, and the other half can't find it. There are nights I wish we had lost at the Trident. Ah, no, not truly, but…
dialogues.speaker: Robert I Baratheon

dialogues.text: I understand.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: I think you do. If so, you are the only one, my old friend. Lord Eddard Stark, I would name you the Hand of the King.
dialogues.speaker: Robert I Baratheon

dialogues.text: Your Grace. I am not worthy of the honor.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: If I wanted to honor you, I'd let you retire. I am planning to make you run the kingdom and fight the wars while I eat and drink and wench myself into an early grave. You know the saying, about the king and his Hand?
dialogues.speaker: Robert I Baratheon

dialogues.text: What the king dreams, the Hand builds.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: I bedded a fishmaid once who told me the lowborn have a choicer way to put it. The king eats, they say, and the Hand takes the shit.
dialogues.speaker: Robert I Baratheon

dialogues.text: Damn it, Ned. You might at least humor me with a smile.
dialogues.speaker: Robert I Baratheon

dialogues.text: They say it grows so cold up here in winter that a man's laughter freezes in his throat and chokes him to death. Perhaps that is why the Starks have so little humor.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Come south with me, and I'll teach you how to laugh again. You helped me win this damnable throne, now help me hold it. We were meant to rule together. If Lyanna had lived, we should have been brothers, bound by blood as well as affection. Well, it is not too late. I have a son. You have a daughter. My Joff and your Sansa shall join our houses, as Lyanna and I might once have done.
dialogues.speaker: Robert I Baratheon

dialogues.text: Sansa is only eleven.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Old enough for betrothal. The marriage can wait a few years. Now stand up and say yes, curse you.
dialogues.speaker: Robert I Baratheon

dialogues.text: Nothing would give me greater pleasure, Your Grace. These honors are all so unexpected. May I have some time to consider? I need to tell my wife…
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Yes, yes, of course, tell Catelyn, sleep on it if you must. Just don't keep me waiting too long. I am not the most patient of men.
dialogues.speaker: Robert I Baratheon

dialogues.text: Hungry again?
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: Is this one of the direwolves I've heard so much of?
dialogues.speaker: Benjen Stark

dialogues.text: Yes. His name is Ghost.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: Summerwine. Nothing so sweet. How many cups have you had, Jon?
dialogues.speaker: Benjen Stark

dialogues.text: As I feared. Ah, well. I believe I was younger than you the first time I got truly and sincerely drunk.
dialogues.speaker: Benjen Stark

dialogues.text: A very quiet wolf.
dialogues.speaker: Benjen Stark

dialogues.text: He's not like the others. He never makes a sound. That's why I named him Ghost. That, and because he's white. The others are all dark, grey or black.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: There are still direwolves beyond the Wall. We hear them on our rangings. Don't you usually eat at table with your brothers?
dialogues.speaker: Benjen Stark

dialogues.text: Most times. But tonight Lady Stark thought it might give insult to the royal family to seat a bastard among them.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: I see. My brother does not seem very festive tonight.
dialogues.speaker: Benjen Stark

dialogues.text: The queen is angry too. Father took the king down to the crypts this afternoon. The queen didn't want him to go.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: You don't miss much, do you, Jon? We could use a man like you on the Wall.
dialogues.speaker: Benjen Stark

dialogues.text: Robb is a stronger lance than I am, but I'm the better sword, and Hullen says I sit a horse as well as anyone in the castle.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: Notable achievements.
dialogues.speaker: Benjen Stark

dialogues.text: Take me with you when you go back to the Wall. Father will give me leave to go if you ask him, I know he will.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: The Wall is a hard place for a boy, Jon.
dialogues.speaker: Benjen Stark

dialogues.text: I am almost a man grown. I will turn fifteen on my next name day, and Maester Luwin says bastards grow up faster than other children.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: That's true enough.
dialogues.speaker: Benjen Stark

dialogues.text: Daeren Targaryen was only fourteen when he conquered Dorne.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: A conquest that lasted a summer. Your Boy King lost ten thousand men taking the place, and another fifty trying to hold it. Someone should have told him that war isn't a game. Also, Daeren Targaryen was only eighteen when he died. Or have you forgotten that part?
dialogues.speaker: Benjen Stark

dialogues.text: I forget nothing. I want to serve in the Night's Watch, Uncle.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: You don't know what you're asking, Jon. The Night's Watch is a sworn brotherhood. We have no families. None of us will ever father sons. Our wife is duty. Our mistress is honor.
dialogues.speaker: Benjen Stark

dialogues.text: A bastard can have honor too. I am ready to swear your oath.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: You are a boy of fourteen. Not a man, not yet. Until you have known a woman, you cannot understand what you would be giving up.
dialogues.speaker: Benjen Stark

dialogues.text: I don't care about that!
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: You might, if you knew what it meant. If you knew what the oath would cost you, you might be less eager to pay the price, son.
dialogues.speaker: Benjen Stark

dialogues.text: I'm not your son!
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: More's the pity. Come back to me after you've fathered a few bastards of your own, and we'll see how you feel.
dialogues.speaker: Benjen Stark

dialogues.text: I will never father a bastard. Never! I must be excused.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: Boy. Is that animal a wolf?
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: A direwolf. His name is Ghost. What are you doing up there? Why aren't you at the feast?
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: Too hot, too noisy, and I'd drunk too much wine. I learned long ago that it is considered rude to vomit on your brother. Might I have a closer look at your wolf?
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: Can you climb down, or shall I bring a ladder?
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: Oh, bleed that.
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: I believe I've frightened your wolf. My apologies.
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: He's not scared.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: Ghost, come here. Come on. That's it.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: Shy, isn't he?
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: Sit, Ghost. That's it. Keep still.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: You can touch him now. He won't move until I tell him to. I've been training him.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: I see. Nice wolf.
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: If I wasn't here, he'd tear out your throat.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: In that case, you had best stay close. I am Tyrion Lannister.
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: I know.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: You're Ned Stark's bastard, aren't you?
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: Did I offend you? Sorry. Dwarfs don't have to be tactful. Generations of capering fools in motley have won me the right to dress badly and say any damn thing that comes into my head. You are the bastard, though.
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: Lord Eddard Stark is my father.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: Yes. I can see it. You have more of the north in you than your brothers.
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: Half brothers.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: Let me give you some counsel, bastard. Never forget what you are, for surely the world will not. Make it your strength. Then it can never be your weakness. Armor yourself in it, and it will never be used to hurt you.
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: What do you know about being a bastard?
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: All dwarfs are bastards in their father's eyes.
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: You are your mother's trueborn son of Lannister.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: Am I? Do tell my lord father. My mother died birthing me, and he's never been sure.
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: I don't even know who my mother was.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: Some woman, no doubt. Most of them are. Remember this, boy. All dwarfs may be bastards, yet not all bastards need be dwarfs.
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: I will refuse him.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: You cannot. You must not.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: My duties are here in the north. I have no wish to be Robert's Hand.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: He will not understand that. He is a king now, and kings are not like other men. If you refuse to serve him, he will wonder why, and sooner or later he will begin to suspect that you oppose him. Can't you see the danger that would put us in?
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: Robert would never harm me or any of mine. We were closer than brothers. He loves me. If I refuse him, he will roar and curse and bluster, and in a week we will laugh about it together. I know the man!
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: You knew the man. The king is a stranger to you. Pride is everything to a king, my lord. Robert came all this way to see you, to bring you these great honors, you cannot throw them back in his face.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: Honors?
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: In his eyes, yes.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: And in yours?
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: And in mine. He offers his own son in marriage to our daughter, what else would you call that? Sansa might someday be queen. Her sons could rule from the Wall to the mountains of Dorne. What is so wrong with that?
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: Gods, Catelyn, Sansa is only eleven. And Joffrey… Joffrey is…
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: …crown prince, and heir to the Iron Throne. And I was only twelve when my father promised me to your brother Brandon.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: Brandon. Yes. Brandon would know what to do. He always did. It was all meant for Brandon. You, Winterfell, everything. He was born to be a King's Hand and a father to queens. I never asked for this cup to pass to me.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Perhaps not, but Brandon is dead, and the cup has passed, and you must drink from it, like it or not.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: What is it?
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: My lord, Maester Luwin is without and begs urgent audience.
dialogues.speaker: Desmond

dialogues.text: You told him I had left orders not to be disturbed?
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Yes, my lord. He insists.
dialogues.speaker: Desmond

dialogues.text: Very well. Send him in.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Perhaps we should close the windows
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: My lord, pardon for disturbing your rest. I have been left a message.
dialogues.speaker: Luwin

dialogues.text: Been left? By whom? Has there been a rider? I was not told.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: There was no rider, my lord. Only a carved wooden box, left on a table in my observatory while I napped. My servants saw no one, but it must have been brought by someone in the king's party. We have had no other visitors from the south.
dialogues.speaker: Luwin

dialogues.text: A wooden box, you say?
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: Inside was a fine new lens for the observatory, from Myr by the look of it. The lenscrafters of Myr are without equal.
dialogues.speaker: Luwin

dialogues.text: A lens. What has that to do with me?
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: I asked the same question. Clearly there was more to this than the seeming.
dialogues.speaker: Luwin

dialogues.text: A lens is an instrument to help us see.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: Indeed it is.
dialogues.speaker: Luwin

dialogues.text: What is it that they would have us see more clearly?
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: The very thing I asked myself. I found the true message concealed within a false bottom when I dismantled the box the lens had come in, but it is not for my eyes.
dialogues.speaker: Luwin

dialogues.text: Let me have it, then.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Pardons, my lord. The message is not for you either. It is marked for the eyes of the Lady Catelyn, and her alone. May I approach?
dialogues.speaker: Luwin

dialogues.text: Stay.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: What is it? My lady, you're shaking.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: I'm afraid. It's from Lysa. It will not make us glad. There is grief in this message, Ned. I can feel it.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: Open it.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Lysa took no chances. When we were girls together, we had a private language, she and I.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: Can you read it?
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Yes.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: Then tell us.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Perhaps I should withdraw.
dialogues.speaker: Luwin

dialogues.text: No. We will need your counsel.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: What are you doing?
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Lighting a fire.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: Maester Luwin—
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Maester Luwin has delivered all my children. This is no time for false modesty.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: My lady, tell me! What was this message?
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: A warning. If we have the wits to hear.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: Go on.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Lysa says Jon Arryn was murdered.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: By whom?
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: The Lannisters. The queen.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: Gods. Your sister is sick with grief. She cannot know what she is saying.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: She knows. Lysa is impulsive, yes, but this message was carefully planned, cleverly hidden. She knew it meant death if her letter fell into the wrong hands. To risk so much, she must have had more than mere suspicion. Now we truly have no choice. You must be Robert's Hand. You must go south with him and learn the truth.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: he only truths I know are here. The south is a nest of adders I would do better to avoid.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: The Hand of the King has great power, my lord. Power to find the truth of Lord Arryn's death, to bring his killers to the king's justice. Power to protect Lady Arryn and her son, if the worst be true.
dialogues.speaker: Luwin

dialogues.text: You say you love Robert like a brother. Would you leave your brother surrounded by Lannisters?
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: The Others take both of you. My father went south once, to answer the summons of a king. He never came home again.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: A different time. A different king.
dialogues.speaker: Luwin

dialogues.text: Yes. Catelyn, you shall stay here in Winterfell.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: No.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: Yes. You must govern the north in my stead, while I run Robert's errands. There must always be a Stark in Winterfell. Robb is fourteen. Soon enough, he will be a man grown. He must learn to rule, and I will not be here for him. Make him part of your councils. He must be ready when his time comes.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Gods will, not for many years.
dialogues.speaker: Luwin

dialogues.text: Maester Luwin, I trust you as I would my own blood. Give my wife your voice in all things great and small. Teach my son the things he needs to know. Winter is coming.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: What of the other children?
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: Rickon is very young. He should stay here with you and Robb. The others I would take with me.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: I could not bear it.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: You must. Sansa must wed Joffrey, that is clear now, we must give them no grounds to suspect our devotion. And it is past time that Arya learned the ways of a southron court. In a few years she will be of an age to marry too.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Yes, but please, Ned, for the love you bear me, let Bran remain here at Winterfell. He is only seven.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: I was eight when my father sent me to foster at the Eyrie. Ser Rodrik tells me there is bad feeling between Robb and Prince Joffrey. That is not healthy. Bran can bridge that distance. He is a sweet boy, quick to laugh, easy to love. Let him grow up with the young princes, let him become their friend as Robert became mine. Our House will be the safer for it.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Keep him off the walls, then. You know how Bran loves to climb.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: Thank you, my lady. This is hard, I know.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: What of Jon Snow, my lord?
dialogues.speaker: Luwin

dialogues.text: Jon must go.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: He and Robb are close. I had hoped…
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: He cannot stay here. He is your son, not mine. I will not have him.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: You know I cannot take him south. There will be no place for him at court. A boy with a bastard's name… you know what they will say of him. He will be shunned.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: They say your friend Robert has fathered a dozen bastards himself.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: And none of them has ever been seen at court! The Lannister woman has seen to that. How can you be so damnably cruel, Catelyn? He is only a boy. He—
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: Another solution presents itself. Your brother Benjen came to me about Jon a few days ago. It seems the boy aspires to take the black.
dialogues.speaker: Luwin

dialogues.text: He asked to join the Night's Watch?
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: There is great honor in service on the Wall, my lord.
dialogues.speaker: Luwin

dialogues.text: And even a bastard may rise high in the Night's Watch. Jon is so young. If he asked this when he was a man grown, that would be one thing, but a boy of fourteen…
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: A hard sacrifice. Yet these are hard times, my lord. His road is no crueler than yours or your lady's.
dialogues.speaker: Luwin

dialogues.text: Very well. I suppose it is for the best. I will speak to Ben.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: When shall we tell Jon?
dialogues.speaker: Luwin

dialogues.text: When I must. Preparations must be made. It will be a fortnight before we are ready to depart. I would sooner let Jon enjoy these last few days. Summer will end soon enough, and childhood as well. When the time comes, I will tell him myself.
dialogues.speaker: Eddard Stark

dialogues.text: What are you talking about? Tell me.
dialogues.speaker: Arya Stark

dialogues.text: We were talking about the prince.
dialogues.speaker: Sansa Stark

dialogues.text: Joffrey likes your sister. He told her she was very beautiful.
dialogues.speaker: Jeyne Poole

dialogues.text: He's going to marry her. Then Sansa will be queen of all the realm.
dialogues.speaker: Beth Cassel

dialogues.text: Beth, you shouldn't make up stories.
dialogues.speaker: Sansa Stark

dialogues.text: What did you think of Prince Joff, sister? He's very gallant, don't you think?
dialogues.speaker: Sansa Stark

dialogues.text: Jon says he looks like a girl.
dialogues.speaker: Arya Stark

dialogues.text: Poor Jon. He gets jealous because he's a bastard.
dialogues.speaker: Sansa Stark

dialogues.text: He's our brother.
dialogues.speaker: Arya Stark

dialogues.text: What are you talking about, children?
dialogues.speaker: Mordane

dialogues.text: Our half brother. Arya and I were remarking on how pleased we were to have the princess with us today.
dialogues.speaker: Sansa Stark

dialogues.text: Indeed. A great honor for us all.
dialogues.speaker: Mordane

dialogues.text: Arya, why aren't you at work? Let me see your stitches.
dialogues.speaker: Mordane

dialogues.text: Here.
dialogues.speaker: Arya Stark

dialogues.text: Arya, Arya, Arya. This will not do. This will not do at all.
dialogues.speaker: Mordane

dialogues.text: Arya, come back here! Don't you take another step! Your lady mother will hear of this. In front of our royal princess too! You'll shame us all!
dialogues.speaker: Mordane

dialogues.text: By your leave, my lady.
dialogues.speaker: Arya Stark

dialogues.text: Just where do you think you are going, Arya?
dialogues.speaker: Mordane

dialogues.text: I have to go shoe a horse.
dialogues.speaker: Arya Stark

dialogues.text: Come.
dialogues.speaker: Arya Stark

dialogues.text: Shouldn't you be working on your stitches, little sister?
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: I wanted to see them fight.
dialogues.speaker: Arya Stark

dialogues.text: Come here, then. A shade more exhausting than needlework.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: A shade more fun than needlework. Why aren't you down in the yard?
dialogues.speaker: Arya Stark

dialogues.text: Bastards are not allowed to damage young princes. Any bruises they take in the practice yard must come from trueborn swords.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: Oh. I could do just as good as Bran. He's only seven. I'm nine.
dialogues.speaker: Arya Stark

dialogues.text: You're too skinny. I doubt you could even lift a longsword, little sister, never mind swing one.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: You see Prince Joffrey? Look at the arms on his surcoat. The Lannisters are proud. You'd think the royal sigil would be sufficient, but no. He makes his mother's House equal in honor to the king's.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: The woman is important too!
dialogues.speaker: Arya Stark

dialogues.text: Perhaps you should do the same thing, little sister. Wed Tully to Stark in your arms.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: A wolf with a fish in its mouth? That would look silly. Besides, if a girl can't fight, why should she have a coat of arms?
dialogues.speaker: Arya Stark

dialogues.text: Girls get the arms but not the swords. Bastards get the swords but not the arms. I did not make the rules, little sister.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: Enough!
dialogues.speaker: Rodrik Cassel

dialogues.text: Well fought. Lew, Donnis, help them out of their armor.
dialogues.speaker: Rodrik Cassel

dialogues.text: Prince Joffrey, Robb, will you go another round?
dialogues.speaker: Rodrik Cassel

dialogues.text: Gladly.
dialogues.speaker: Robb Stark

dialogues.text: This is a game for children, Ser Rodrik.
dialogues.speaker: Joffrey Baratheon

dialogues.text: You are children.
dialogues.speaker: Theon Greyjoy

dialogues.text: Robb may be a child. I am a prince. And I grow tired of swatting at Starks with a play sword.
dialogues.speaker: Joffrey Baratheon

dialogues.text: You got more swats than you gave, Joff. Are you afraid?
dialogues.speaker: Robb Stark

dialogues.text: Oh, terrified. You're so much older.
dialogues.speaker: Joffrey Baratheon

dialogues.text: Joffrey is truly a little shit.
dialogues.speaker: Arya Stark

dialogues.text: What are you suggesting?
dialogues.speaker: Rodrik Cassel

dialogues.text: Live steel.
dialogues.speaker: Joffrey Baratheon

dialogues.text: Done. You'll be sorry!
dialogues.speaker: Robb Stark

dialogues.text: Live steel is too dangerous. I will permit you tourney swords, with blunted edges.
dialogues.speaker: Rodrik Cassel

dialogues.text: This is your prince. Who are you to tell him he may not have an edge on his sword, ser?
dialogues.speaker: Sandor Clegane

dialogues.text: Master-at-arms of Winterfell, Clegane, and you would do well not to forget it.
dialogues.speaker: Rodrik Cassel

dialogues.text: Are you training women here?
dialogues.speaker: Sandor Clegane

dialogues.text: I am training knights. They will have steel when they are ready. When they are of an age.
dialogues.speaker: Rodrik Cassel

dialogues.text: How old are you, boy?
dialogues.speaker: Sandor Clegane

dialogues.text: Fourteen.
dialogues.speaker: Robb Stark

dialogues.text: I killed a man at twelve. You can be sure it was not with a blunt sword.
dialogues.speaker: Sandor Clegane

dialogues.text: Let me do it. I can beat him.
dialogues.speaker: Robb Stark

dialogues.text: Beat him with a tourney blade, then.
dialogues.speaker: Rodrik Cassel

dialogues.text: Come and see me when you're older, Stark. If you're not too old.
dialogues.speaker: Joffrey Baratheon

dialogues.text: Come, Tommen. The hour of play is done. Leave the children to their frolics.
dialogues.speaker: Joffrey Baratheon

dialogues.text: The show is done. You had best run back to your room, little sister. Septa Mordane will surely be lurking. The longer you hide, the sterner the penance. You'll be sewing all through winter. When the spring thaw comes, they will find your body with a needle still locked tight between your frozen fingers.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: I hate needlework! It's not fair!
dialogues.speaker: Arya Stark

dialogues.text: Nothing is fair.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: You stay here. Lie down. That's right. Now stay—
dialogues.speaker: Bran Stark

dialogues.text: Quiet. Sit down. Stay. You're worse than Mother.
dialogues.speaker: Bran Stark

dialogues.text: I do not like it. You should be the Hand.
dialogues.speaker: Cersei Lannister

dialogues.text: Gods forbid. It's not an honor I'd want. There's far too much work involved.
dialogues.speaker: Jaime Lannister

dialogues.text: Don't you see the danger this puts us in? Robert loves the man like a brother.
dialogues.speaker: Cersei Lannister

dialogues.text: Robert can barely stomach his brothers. Not that I blame him. Stannis would be enough to give anyone indigestion.
dialogues.speaker: Jaime Lannister

dialogues.text: Don't play the fool. Stannis and Renly are one thing, and Eddard Stark is quite another. Robert will listen to Stark. Damn them both. I should have insisted that he name you, but I was certain Stark would refuse him.
dialogues.speaker: Cersei Lannister

dialogues.text: We ought to count ourselves fortunate. The king might as easily have named one of his brothers, or even Littlefinger, gods help us. Give me honorable enemies rather than ambitious ones, and I'll sleep more easily by night.
dialogues.speaker: Jaime Lannister

dialogues.text: We will have to watch him carefully.
dialogues.speaker: Cersei Lannister

dialogues.text: I would sooner watch you. Come back here.
dialogues.speaker: Jaime Lannister

dialogues.text: Lord Eddard has never taken any interest in anything that happened south of the Neck. Never. I tell you, he means to move against us. Why else would he leave the seat of his power?
dialogues.speaker: Cersei Lannister

dialogues.text: A hundred reasons. Duty. Honor. He yearns to write his name large across the book of history, to get away from his wife, or both. Perhaps he just wants to be warm for once in his life.
dialogues.speaker: Jaime Lannister

dialogues.text: His wife is Lady Arryn's sister. It's a wonder Lysa was not here to greet us with her accusations.
dialogues.speaker: Cersei Lannister

dialogues.text: You fret too much. Lysa Arryn is a frightened cow.
dialogues.speaker: Jaime Lannister

dialogues.text: That frightened cow shared Jon Arryn's bed.
dialogues.speaker: Cersei Lannister

dialogues.text: If she knew anything, she would have gone to Robert before she fled King's Landing.
dialogues.speaker: Jaime Lannister

dialogues.text: When he had already agreed to foster that weakling son of hers at Casterly Rock? I think not. She knew the boy's life would be hostage to her silence. She may grow bolder now that he's safe atop the Eyrie.
dialogues.speaker: Cersei Lannister

dialogues.text: Mothers. I think birthing does something to your minds. You are all mad. Let Lady Arryn grow as bold as she likes. Whatever she knows, whatever she thinks she knows, she has no proof. Or does she?
dialogues.speaker: Jaime Lannister

dialogues.text: Do you think the king will require proof? I tell you, he loves me not.
dialogues.speaker: Cersei Lannister

dialogues.text: And whose fault is that, sweet sister?
dialogues.speaker: Jaime Lannister

dialogues.text: You are as blind as Robert.
dialogues.speaker: Cersei Lannister

dialogues.text: If you mean I see the same thing, yes. I see a man who would sooner die than betray his king.
dialogues.speaker: Jaime Lannister

dialogues.text: He betrayed one already, or have you forgotten? Oh, I don't deny he's loyal to Robert, that's obvious. What happens when Robert dies and Joff takes the throne? And the sooner that comes to pass, the safer we'll all be. My husband grows more restless every day. Having Stark beside him will only make him worse. He's still in love with the sister, the insipid little dead sixteen-year-old. How long till he decides to put me aside for some new Lyanna?
dialogues.speaker: Cersei Lannister

dialogues.text: You should think less about the future and more about the pleasures at hand.
dialogues.speaker: Jaime Lannister

dialogues.text: Stop that!
dialogues.speaker: Cersei Lannister

dialogues.text: All this talk is getting very tiresome, sister. Come here and be quiet.
dialogues.speaker: Jaime Lannister

dialogues.text: Stop it, stop it, stop it. Oh, please… He saw us.
dialogues.speaker: Cersei Lannister

dialogues.text: So he did.
dialogues.speaker: Jaime Lannister

dialogues.text: Take my hand. Before you fall.
dialogues.speaker: Jaime Lannister

dialogues.text: What are you doing?
dialogues.speaker: Cersei Lannister

dialogues.text: How old are you, boy?
dialogues.speaker: Jaime Lannister

dialogues.text: Seven.
dialogues.speaker: Bran Stark

dialogues.text: The things I do for love.
dialogues.speaker: Jaime Lannister

dialogues.text: Chayle. I'm off to break my fast. See that you return the books to the shelves. Be gentle with the Valyrian scrolls, the parchment is very dry. Ayrmidon's Engines of War is quite rare, and yours is the only complete copy I've ever seen.
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: The boy is a long time dying. I wish he would be quicker about it.
dialogues.speaker: Sandor Clegane

dialogues.text: At least he dies quietly. It's the wolf that makes the noise. I could scarce sleep last night.
dialogues.speaker: Joffrey Baratheon

dialogues.text: I could silence the creature, if it please you.
dialogues.speaker: Sandor Clegane

dialogues.text: Send a dog to kill a dog! Winterfell is so infested with wolves, the Starks would never miss one.
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: I beg to differ, nephew. The Starks can count past six. Unlike some princes I might name.
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: A voice from nowhere. Spirits of the air!
dialogues.speaker: Sandor Clegane

dialogues.text: Down here.
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: The little lord Tyrion. My pardons. I did not see you standing there.
dialogues.speaker: Sandor Clegane

dialogues.text: I am in no mood for your insolence today.
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: Joffrey, it is past time you called on Lord Eddard and his lady, to offer them your comfort.
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: What good will my comfort do them?
dialogues.speaker: Joffrey Baratheon

dialogues.text: None. Yet it is expected of you. Your absence has been noted.
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: The Stark boy is nothing to me. I cannot abide the wailing of women.
dialogues.speaker: Joffrey Baratheon

dialogues.text: One word, and I will hit you again.
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: I'm going to tell Mother!
dialogues.speaker: Joffrey Baratheon

dialogues.text: You tell your mother. But first you get yourself to Lord and Lady Stark, and you fall to your knees in front of them, and you tell them how very sorry you are, and that you are at their service if there is the slightest thing you can do for them or theirs in this desperate hour, and that all your prayers go with them. Do you understand? Do you?
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: The prince will remember that, little lord.
dialogues.speaker: Sandor Clegane

dialogues.text: I pray he does. If he forgets, be a good dog and remind him. Do you know where I might find my brother?
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: Breaking fast with the queen.
dialogues.speaker: Sandor Clegane

dialogues.text: Ah.
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: Is Robert still abed?
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: The king has not slept at all. He is with Lord Eddard. He has taken their sorrow deeply to heart.
dialogues.speaker: Cersei Lannister

dialogues.text: He has a large heart, our Robert.
dialogues.speaker: Jaime Lannister

dialogues.text: Bread, and two of those little fish, and a mug of that good dark beer to wash them down. Oh, and some bacon. Burn it until it turns black.
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: Do you have news of Bran, Uncle?
dialogues.speaker: Tommen Baratheon

dialogues.text: I stopped by the sickroom last night. There was no change. The maester thought that a hopeful sign.
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: I don't want Brandon to die.
dialogues.speaker: Tommen Baratheon

dialogues.text: Lord Eddard had a brother named Brandon as well. One of the hostages murdered by Targaryen. It seems to be an unlucky name.
dialogues.speaker: Jaime Lannister

dialogues.text: Oh, not so unlucky as all that, surely.
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: What do you mean?
dialogues.speaker: Cersei Lannister

dialogues.text: Why, only that Tommen may get his wish. The maester thinks the boy may yet live.
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: That is no mercy. These northern gods are cruel to let the child linger in such pain.
dialogues.speaker: Cersei Lannister

dialogues.text: What were the maester's words?
dialogues.speaker: Jaime Lannister

dialogues.text: He thinks that if the boy were going to die, he would have done so already. It has been four days with no change.
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: Will Bran get better, Uncle?
dialogues.speaker: Myrcella Baratheon

dialogues.text: His back is broken, little one. The fall shattered his legs as well. They keep him alive with honey and water, or he would starve to death. Perhaps, if he wakes, he will be able to eat real food, but he will never walk again.
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: If he wakes. Is that likely?
dialogues.speaker: Cersei Lannister

dialogues.text: The gods alone know. The maester only hopes. I would swear that wolf of his is keeping the boy alive. The creature is outside his window day and night, howling. Every time they chase it away, it returns. The maester said they closed the window once, to shut out the noise, and Bran seemed to weaken. When they opened it again, his heart beat stronger.
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: There is something unnatural about those animals. They are dangerous. I will not have any of them coming south with us.
dialogues.speaker: Cersei Lannister

dialogues.text: You'll have a hard time stopping them, sister. They follow those girls everywhere.
dialogues.speaker: Jaime Lannister

dialogues.text: Are you leaving soon, then?
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: Not near soon enough.
dialogues.speaker: Cersei Lannister

dialogues.text: Are we leaving? What about you? Gods, don't tell me you are staying here?
dialogues.speaker: Cersei Lannister

dialogues.text: Benjen Stark is returning to the Night's Watch with his brother's bastard. I have a mind to go with them and see this Wall we have all heard so much of.
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: I hope you're not thinking of taking the black on us, sweet brother.
dialogues.speaker: Jaime Lannister

dialogues.text: What, me, celibate? The whores would go begging from Dorne to Casterly Rock. No, I just want to stand on top of the Wall and piss off the edge of the world.
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: The children don't need to hear this filth. Tommen, Myrcella, come.
dialogues.speaker: Cersei Lannister

dialogues.text: Stark will never consent to leave Winterfell with his son lingering in the shadow of death.
dialogues.speaker: Jaime Lannister

dialogues.text: He will if Robert commands it. And Robert will command it. There is nothing Lord Eddard can do for the boy in any case.
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: He could end his torment. I would, if it were my son. It would be a mercy.
dialogues.speaker: Jaime Lannister

dialogues.text: I advise against putting that suggestion to Lord Eddard, sweet brother. He would not take it kindly.
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: Even if the boy does live, he will be a cripple. Worse than a cripple. A grotesque. Give me a good clean death.
dialogues.speaker: Jaime Lannister

dialogues.text: Speaking for the grotesques. I beg to differ. Death is so terribly final, while life is full of possibilities.
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: You are a perverse little imp, aren't you?
dialogues.speaker: Jaime Lannister

dialogues.text: Oh, yes. I hope the boy does wake. I would be most interested to hear what he might have to say.
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: Tyrion, my sweet brother, there are times when you give me cause to wonder whose side you are on.
dialogues.speaker: Jaime Lannister

dialogues.text: Why, Jaime, my sweet brother, you wound me. You know how much I love my family.
dialogues.speaker: Tyrion Lannister

dialogues.text: What are you doing here?
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: I came to see Bran. To say good-bye.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: You've said it. Now go away.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: Please.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: I told you to leave. We don't want you here.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: He's my brother.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: Shall I call the guards?
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: Call them. You can't stop me from seeing him.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: Bran. I'm sorry I didn't come before. I was afraid. Don't die, Bran. Please. We're all waiting for you to wake up. Me and Robb and the girls, everyone…
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: I have to go now. Uncle Benjen is waiting. I'm to go north to the Wall. We have to leave today, before the snows come.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: I wanted him to stay here with me. I prayed for it. He was my special boy. I went to the sept and prayed seven times to the seven faces of god that Ned would change his mind and leave him here with me. Sometimes prayers are answered.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: It wasn't your fault.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: I need none of your absolution, bastard.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: Good-bye.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: Jon.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: Yes?
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: It should have been you.
dialogues.speaker: Catelyn Stark

dialogues.text: Uncle Benjen is looking for you. He wanted to be gone an hour ago.
dialogues.speaker: Robb Stark

dialogues.text: I know. Soon. Leaving is harder than I thought.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: For me too. Did you see him?
dialogues.speaker: Robb Stark

dialogues.text: He's not going to die. I know it.
dialogues.speaker: Robb Stark

dialogues.text: You Starks are hard to kill.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow

dialogues.text: My mother…
dialogues.speaker: Robb Stark

dialogues.text: She was… very kind.
dialogues.speaker: Jon Snow
